skills.name: Recognise the place value of each digit in integers
Recognise the place value of each digit in decimals

explanations.A: I think you have found the number in the hundreds column, we need the number in the hundredths column
explanations.B: The 4 is in the tenths column. Which column will be hundredths?
explanations.C: After the decimal point we have the tenths column, and then the hundredths column. That means the 5 is in the hundredths position
explanations.D: Not quite. The 6 is in the thousandths column. Which column will be hundredths?

explanations.A: I think you have found the number in the tens column, we need the number in the tenths column
explanations.B: Not quite, this is the units column. Which column will be tenths?
explanations.C: After the decimal point we have the tenths column. That means the 4 is in the tenths position
explanations.D: Not quite, the 5 is in the hundredths column. Which column is the tenths?

explanations.A: The 5 is not in the tens column. Use a place value grid, putting the 7 in the units column, the 3 in the tens column and so on, to help you decide the value of the number 5.
explanations.B: The 5 is not in the units column. Use a place value grid, putting the 7 in the units column, the 3 in the tens column and so on, to help you decide the value of the number 5.
explanations.C: If we put this number in a place value grid the number 5 would go in the thousands column. Therefore this 5 represents 5 lots of one thousand which is 5000.
explanations.D: The 5 is not in the ten thousands column. Use a place value grid, putting the 7 in the units column, the 3 in the tens column and so on, to help you decide the value of the number 5.

explanations.A: The 3 is not in the units column. Use a place value grid, putting the 0 in the units column, the 5 in the tens column and so on, to help you decide the value of the number 3.
explanations.B: If we put this number in a place value grid the number 3 would go in the hundred thousands column. Therefore this 3 represents 3 lots of one hundred thousand which is 300,000.
explanations.C: The 3 is not in the ten thousands column. Use a place value grid, putting the 0 in the units column, the 5 in the tens column and so on, to help you decide the value of the number 3.
explanations.D: The 3 is not in the hundreds column. Use a place value grid, putting the 0 in the units column, the 5 in the tens column and so on, to help you decide the value of the number 3.

explanations.A: This is the digit 3, but we need its place value. The 0 is in the ones column. What do we label the columns after the decimal point?
explanations.B: Not quite! Label each column along from the decimal point.
explanations.C: This would represent 30 if we did not have the decimal point and our number was 2537, but the decimal point changes the place value. What do we label each column after the decimal point?
explanations.D: The 0 is in the ones column, the 2 represents 2/10 as it is in the tenths column, the 5 represents 5/100 as it is in the hundredths column. Therefore the 3 represents 3/1000 as it is in the thousandths column.

explanations.A: This would represent 400 if we did not have the decimal point and our number was 1467, but the decimal point changes the place value. What do we label each column after the decimal point?
explanations.B: The 0 is in the ones column, the 1 represents 1/10 as it is in the tenths column, the 4 represents 4/100 as it is in the hundredths column.
explanations.C: Not quite! Label each column along from the decimal point.
explanations.D: This is the digit 4, but we need its place value. The 0 is in the ones column. What do we label the columns after the decimal point?

explanations.A: The 3 is in the tens column, so will be worth 3 x 10 = 30.
explanations.B: This is 3 units, or 3 x 1, which would position it in the far right column.
explanations.C: This is 300, or 3 x 100. This would position the 3 in the third column from the right.
explanations.D: This is 3000, or 3 x 1000, which would position the 3 on the 4th column from the right.

explanations.A: This is 4 units, or 4 x 1, which would position it in the far right column.
explanations.B: The 4 is in the tens column, so will be worth 4 x 10 = 40.
explanations.C: This is 400, or 4 x 100. This would position the 4 in the third column from the right.
explanations.D: This is 4000, or 4 x 1000, which would position the 4 in the 4th column from the right.

explanations.A: You have just stated the digit. Consider the place value columns and what the 3 is worth in that column.
explanations.B: I think you have read the decimal point or the digit in the wrong place value.
explanations.C: The 3 is in the hundredths column so would be worth 3 hundredths - 0.03.
explanations.D: I think you have read the decimal point or the digit in the wrong place value.

explanations.A: The 6 is in the hundredths column so would be worth 6 hundredths - 0.06.
explanations.B: I think you have read the decimal point or the digit in the wrong place value.
explanations.C: You have just stated the digit. Consider the place value columns and what the 6 is worth in that column.
explanations.D: I think you have read the decimal point or the digit in the wrong place value.
